author: news.sky
title: Nuclear Deal Part Of £30bn China Trade Plan
text:
Trade deals worth £30bn will be discussed later as David Cameron hosts Chinese President Xi Jinping at Downing Street. An announcement is expected on China's contribution to a new nuclear power plant which could open at Hinkley Point in Somerset by 2025.
French energy firm EDF will build the plant, but Beijing is expected to cover around 30% of the £24bn cost.
Among other initiatives being discussed is a £325m package of partnerships in the creative and technology industries, including a £50m deal between Aston Martin and China Equity to develop its zero-emission RapidE sports car.
Britain will also make it easier and cheaper for Chinese tourists to visit the UK, in a bid to boost income from tourism and create more jobs.
Play video "Montage: Day One Of Xi's UK Visit" Video: Montage: Day One Of Xi's UK Visit From January, the price of a two-year, multiple-visit UK visa will be slashed from £324 to £85 - the current cost of a six-month visa.
And plans are also under consideration for the introduction of a 10-year, unlimited entry visa for regular Chinese visitors.
Britain will also extend a mobile fingerprinting service from nine to 50 Chinese cities, allowing more people to easily undertake the biometric procedures required to apply for a visa.
Play video "China's UK Spending Spree" Video: China's UK Spending Spree Announcing the moves, David Cameron said: "China is becoming one of our fastest-growing tourism markets so making it easier and more convenient for Chinese visitors to come to the UK is extremely important.
"That is why the announcement I'm making today is great news for our tourism industry and great news for the British economy enabling us to maximise Chinese spending power even further."
Mr Cameron has also promised the loss of hundreds of jobs in the steel industry will be on the agenda.
Play video "Chinese Visit Sparks Protest" Video: Chinese Visit Sparks Protest The talks come after the Queen hosted a state banquet in honour of Mr Xi at Buckingham Palace on the first full day of his visit to Britain.
Speaking in Mandarin, Mr Xi told attendees: "As China-UK comprehensive strategic partnership enters the second decade this year, let us seize the opportunity and work together to usher in an even brighter future for China-UK relationship."
:: The trade deals and job losses in the steel industry are likely to be hot topics during today's Prime Minister's Questions. Watch live on Sky News from 12 noon.
